Primary_Text: Aájapana tɨɨ iina asúraaja; aájapaki tɨɨ nu=íija.
Translated_Text: That manioc (plant) is unproductive; it has no fruit.

Primary_Text: Iina kaaya aájapana tɨɨ; kaa nu=aámuuyaa kuuwaa.
Translated_Text: That man is unsuccessful; he kills no game.

Primary_Text: Atii kw=aátikura naa , "Jaarí tɨɨ jaa, aájapaki kaimíitu.
Translated_Text: Then I said to them, "That's enough, there's no more caimito.

Primary_Text: Aámiikáaka kí=nakarɨɨkurá aájapaa asúraaja síratáani naajáaja, kaa=kija kí=pariiyaákura.
Translated_Text: Yesterday, although I wanted to harvest manioc also, I couldn’t.

Primary_Text: Kaa jɨɨ́tikari nu=pariiyaárikɨ nu=iíkwajiipɨ atúuni, aájapaa=na na=aakɨsiijaárikɨ nuu, aájapaki.
Translated_Text: She would never tell her family, even if they got her drunk, nothing.
She didn't arrive.

Primary_Text: Atii=na iina máana nu=aátikuráana, “Aákari=na iina p=áaka, aákari nu=ɨɨ́yaaka taa Anatimu.”
Translated_Text: Then the elder spoke, “Now our river, now its name is Anatimu.”

Primary_Text: Yaawɨ́ɨni kutɨ́tɨɨrɨɨ, jɨɨ́ta aákari=na, nu=aátii kíija...
Translated_Text: Another day dawned, like today, and he says to me ...
He sang when he was intoxicated (with ayahuasca).
I was drunk on manioc beer.
They were intoxicated with ayahuasca.

Primary_Text: Aájapaki sinaakɨ kíija, tákaana kw=aamɨ́yaakiaárikɨ, najaápusɨ kuwíini=aákuji.
Translated_Text: I had no clothes, I walked around naked, due to being an orphan.

Primary_Text: Iina kaaya, kɨɨ́raka=aákuji, nu=tikiaárɨɨkiaakɨ=ná tíira, iimi=ɨ́ɨjakúura sɨɨsaramaajɨtáami náana.
Translated_Text: This man, from fear, entered there, inside (i.e., among) the three trees.
Because of that, my relative lives alone there downriver.
She was making her (aunt) go (walk) in front of her, and her dogs behind her.
I went ahead before her to the ‘chacra’ (upriver).
I ate the cooked (manioc) from yesterday.

Primary_Text: Kaa kina=miisaákari niwa, nuú kina aámuu tamɨ́nɨɨna=jata.
Translated_Text: If you don’t do this, he will kill you with lightning.
They strike them (my chickens) in their lower leg bones.
Reinerio played the bass drum.

Primary_Text: Iiti=ji pɨɨ́ pɨ=nuúruu aámuu, nu=iwáani=íira naami iwatáani=iíkuma.
Translated_Text: From here we will pound our barbasco, so that it arrives downriver in the sacarita.

Primary_Text: Iina=wajá anapa, atii nu=ɨɨ́yaa, iinawaja nu=kitɨ́ɨni nu=námaku amuutáani.
Translated_Text: But the macaw, there he flies, and he never stops flapping his wings.
Pow! He struck it (the painted balsa piece) across (perpendicular to) the river.

Primary_Text: Atii=na, jɨɨ́tikari na=aaniísirɨɨ, atii tɨɨ na=iwɨɨ́taa na=inɨ́ɨsi=jina, átiiji na=itɨ́wɨɨ niíya=jina.
Translated_Text: Then, when they were ‘cutipado’ (by <saasakíkwaa>), then there right where they were lying in their hammocks, from there they fell to the ground.

Primary_Text: Anuu táa=na iísuuja nu=aaniísirɨɨ, iísuuja n=ani , n=akɨ kumɨnitaaja=na...
Translated_Text: He was ‘cutipado’ by armadillo, his parents had raised him thus (i.e. feeding him armadillo)...
Shortly thereafter they became very intoxicated (with <saasakíkwaa>).
The ayahuasca has worn off for us.

Primary_Text: Átiiji=jaa, sɨɨsaramaajɨtáami kásiiri aárɨɨkiaakɨ=ná, na=iíjuutakiaakɨ=ná nu=naniijúuni=íira tii nuu=nɨɨ́jina.
Translated_Text: After three months passed, they opened (moved) the pot to sweep above the spot.
What happened to you?
I will pass by running.
A bat passed the top of my head.
They carried water and threw it on them (while they danced).
He said, “Take me.”
I say to her, “You must walk with care, in the forest.”

Primary_Text: Jaari na=iíkwaa míinka=jina nuúrika=ánuurá=yaa taana kaayaaka aríini.
Translated_Text: Nowadays they go to ‘mingas’ only in order to criticize other people.
I intended to cut it on its head.
Yeah, what is it, husband?
We travelled at night, with rain, and (with) strong sun.

Primary_Text: Aájapaa ajaana kuúkirɨɨ jɨɨ́tirimi yaawɨ́ɨni, tii=kija iina iíkii pisúuni, iinawaja jɨɨ́tikari nu=jawɨ́ɨni.
Translated_Text: Despite it being sunny weather for however many days, there where the ‘atinga’ lives, it never dries out.
In the dry season, there are lots of horseflies.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari taa iísakwana iina sakɨ́ɨka=na, saámiita míija iina sakɨ́ɨka=na, nu=ájakuusiíjaa pɨ́=marasi.
Translated_Text: When the mash is sweet, when the mash is recently made, it harms our stomach (i.e., our digestion).
He is weaving ‘batán’-style ‘crisnejas’.

Primary_Text: Iina maaya, nu=ajarakuútaki tíira taarí=yaajaa, aákari kaa.
Translated_Text: That child was on all fours over there earlier (but) not now.

Primary_Text: Iina maaya, nu=ajarakuútasáwɨɨ naami niíyama iyaamiaákuji nu=itɨ́wɨɨ.
Translated_Text: That child is now on all fours there on the ground because he fell.
They landed down at our port.
The paucar landed in that tree.
The other (last) year, she already had a daughter-in-law.
That young woman wants to have a mother-in-law or father-in-law.
I struck a dolphin (with my harpoon), not a person!

Primary_Text: Átiiji=jaa, jɨɨ́tikari taá jawana iina kanuu=na, kiaá iina ájiitaki mírija.
Translated_Text: After that, when the chambira fiber is dry, you’ll mash the ‘mishquipanga’.
The macaw, they say, would sit in the branches of the trees.
He gave me the middle part of the fish (cut in three parts).

Primary_Text: Iina mɨɨnɨɨ, nu=amaniikuútaki iina náana íniija náana akájinaku, nu=kukwáani=íira nuu.
Translated_Text: The capuchin monkey struck the seed against the middle of the tree to break it open.

Primary_Text: Naa=kaa kuuwaa akájinaku nu=inákiaakɨ=wajá naami taása=jinakuma.
Translated_Text: Not even half the meat did he put in the basket.
She tied him to the middle of the tree.

Primary_Text: Iina ikwani, nu=tijákaa iina náana ániija naami nuu=akájinama.
Translated_Text: That man is cutting that felled tree below (us) at its middle.
His machete was stuck in his waist (i.e., worn in this manner).
My grandma’s waist is large.

Primary_Text: Iina ikwaana, nu=siwaánɨkura iina akájinakuúraji náana.
Translated_Text: The flood reached the middle of this tree.
The vinesnake is lying across this path.

Primary_Text: Iina iiyɨɨ, nu=máruu iina=akájinakuúraji náana nuu.
Translated_Text: (As for) the rope, he tied it around the tree trunk.
They lived on the Acamana Quebrada; we lived there upriver (not here downriver) with them.

Primary_Text: Akami=na na=iíkii náaji jɨɨ́ta kaaya iíkii, kaa kánɨɨka sakiíni=jata, kaa kánɨɨka ariíni=jata, kaa ipuruúni=jata, aájapaki.
Translated_Text: Up there (i.e., in heaven, in contrast to on earth), they live how a person should live, hating no-one, criticizing no-one, without fighting, nothing.

Primary_Text: Iina kumaku, nu=akasiítaa, kaa nu=paájii takúuni kamíkiika.
Translated_Text: That old man stands bent forward, he can’t stand up straight anymore.
“Ah!,” yelled the other man.
The ‘guaba’ beside the house is forming a (new) branch.
The wind is blowing strongly.
The wind is blowing strongly.
That man took possession of the canoe.
He had gotten together with a woman.
That young man wants to get a father-in-law or brother-in-law.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari Ines niyaákikiaakɨ́ Elmer=na, Elmer akuúmiikiaakɨ́ Nelson.
Translated_Text: When Ines married Elmer, Elmer became Nelson’s brother-in-law.

Primary_Text: Amaa! Siiríija kuríkɨɨja tɨɨ iina, iina pɨ́=sikɨɨyaárɨɨkura káami tɨɨ p=ɨɨ́kiaakura.
Translated_Text: Oh! This is grandmother’s parrot, whom we left upriver where we used to live.
Oh! Peccaries ate here (upon seeing a trampled garden).

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na tipanɨɨri kásiitakiaakɨ=na n=amákɨjina, nu=apɨɨ́takura nuu.
Translated_Text: Then the stingray monster grabbed in empty space and let him escape.

Primary_Text: Kaa kiaa=tɨ kana=nikikurá jaa; kana=amákɨjina; kiaa=tɨ siwaánɨrɨɨkurá, iwárɨɨja kanáaja jaa.
Translated_Text: You would not have seen us; (only) our absence; you would have arrived, with us already dead.

Primary_Text: Iiná tɨɨ, nikísaa pajataákujina=na, juwáana amákɨku tɨɨ.
Translated_Text: This, which looks like a hole, is the trace of a spear.

Primary_Text: K=iíkwaa nakikúura, kí=paanii kuuwaa; kaá tɨɨ nu=amákɨjina.
Translated_Text: I am going to the forest (and) I will look for game; it is not in vain (i.e., I will encounter game).

Primary_Text: Iipɨ taapɨ aniaárikɨ nu=níwaji, naawaaka na=amákɨɨyaárikɨ uumáana amakɨ jaa.
Translated_Text: Those that came behind him (the leader), they cut a wide path at that point.

Primary_Text: Kw=aátii nuu, “Jɨɨ́tikari kia=kaajiya muuti iriaárɨɨ=na, kiaa amákɨɨ, tɨɨ kiaá nuu tiitaki.”
Translated_Text: I say to her, “When your dogs go off after an agouti, you will cut a path, wherever you follow them.”

Primary_Text: Cristina nu=amakɨ́ɨra, nu=átuuyaárɨɨkura kíija, kí=kwaráani=íira nu=pakarikuji.
Translated_Text: In anticipation of Cristina’s absence, she left having instructed me to weed her front patio.

Primary_Text: Nu=amakɨɨ́taa iimi naaka, nu=takaraajúuni=íira aasamujina=ánuura niwa.
Translated_Text: He is making a path for those tree trunks, so that he can roll them to the creek.
The warriors would kill among themselves.
The hunter killed (many) woolly monkeys.
She is patting the child’s body to make him sleep.
He is pounding the barbasco with his mallet.
I am clapping (my hands) because she sang well.

Primary_Text: Jaari=na nɨɨtamu apárakiaakɨ=ná samɨrɨ́ɨni=jina jaa, iyaamiaákuji kaa nu=ɨɨyaárɨɨ náaji, kaa nu=amaniikuútaa sámɨɨra nu=námaku.
Translated_Text: Then the vulture began to tire, because it doesn’t fly that way, it doesn’t flap its wings rapidly.
That man is acting jealous about his wife.

Primary_Text: Anuu tarawaájuuyaárikɨ=na kuumi amáriyaana jaa, náaji kuuwaa paníini=jata, aamɨ́yaakiáana.
Translated_Text: He had worked for two years already, seeking game in that way, as a hunter.
Suddenly there was a strong wind.

Primary_Text: Kiaa amátanana kuúkirɨɨ kia=kuwíini=íira kuuráaka, iyaamiaákuji kiaa pɨyɨ́ɨni nakusiki, jaátaaraata kiaá iipɨ íyaakitaki, pɨ́=kujímaka iíkii iiti p=ɨ́yiki.
Translated_Text: You have to be strong to be chief, because you have to know about everything, how you should govern those who live here where we live.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari iina kásiitaakura amátana anásaka nuu nu=jíritijina=na, nu=iwɨɨ́taakurá tatɨɨ=iyáaji, jɨɨ́ta sɨɨmɨɨsíini=jata.
Translated_Text: When the pain was afflicting her intensely in her stomach, she lay on the palm floor, as if with cold.

Primary_Text: Atíira kiaá iina amítatakwaa kia=táasa kia=iitakúura, kaa tuu iiti.
Translated_Text: There you will go and open up your basket, at your house, not here.
He already filled his gourd bowl.
Thus my fishtrap fills up inside (with fish).
Wow, (the man was) heavily bearded, his beard (down to) here (gesturing).
If I recuperate, I will go and visit you.

Primary_Text: Anuu=na, anaaraata naajáaja, nu=wɨɨrɨɨ́takiaaná nuu, “Saakaa=na kia=miiyaákiaana, máaya?”
Translated_Text: He, in the very same way, also asked him, “What are you doing, child?”
Our ancestors lived in the headwaters of the Pintuyacu River.

Primary_Text: N=aátikiaákɨ=na, “Iiná tɨɨ kuuta Takarnáaku, iina pɨ́=nakúsii káami nu=anákaku naajáaja.”
Translated_Text: They said, “This may be the Nanay River, which we also know upriver at its headwaters.”

Primary_Text: Naami Ninarumi=jina, anami kana=makɨ́kura, jɨɨ́tikari kana=iíkwakura iiti=ji.
Translated_Text: Downriver in Ninarumi, there downriver we slept when we went from here.

Primary_Text: Anami=na nu=inaárikɨ nu=paápaaja, nu=iríini=íira tíira nu=iitakúura nuu.
Translated_Text: There inside (his leaf basket) he would put his fish, to take it there to his house.

Primary_Text: Ánasa k=iíkii, iyaamiaákuji iina tipanɨɨri nu=asakura kí=maaya maníini.
Translated_Text: I am angry, because the demonic stingray ate my teenage son.
My head was hurting.
This man got injured.
The ‘isula’ (hunting ant) bite is hurting me.
I put legs on the bench.
The ‘isula’ (hunting ant) is hurting me (from its bite).

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, iina ikwani aniaárikɨ, n=akúumi aniaárikɨ nuu=ánuura.
Translated_Text: So thus that man approached, her son-in-law came for her.

Primary_Text: Iyaamiaákuji aákari, kuukisaákari aámiikáaka, iipɨ siwaánɨrɨɨ kaayaaka, iipɨ ánii p=aamúuni=ánuura.
Translated_Text: Because today, or perhaps tomorrow, the people who are coming to kill us will arrive.

Primary_Text: Aájapaki=kija, kaa iina ánii uumáata aasi, niwa=aákuji kaa kí=pariíyaa iina jikatáani ki=náana iíkii aasamu=jina.
Translated_Text: But no, it didn’t rain heavily, and that is why I can’t take my wood out that is in the creek.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari nu=ikwaánɨɨyaárikɨ aasamu=na, kana=iikwaárikɨ niínaki tarawaajúuni=ánuura, kana=ijíkatatáani=íira iina náana, jɨɨ́tikari nu=aniaárikɨ.
Translated_Text: When the creeks flooded, we went to work at night, in order to push out the logs, when it rained.
It (a jaguar) curled up its tail.

Primary_Text: Nu=pajámani tɨɨ iina pajataárikɨ iina tasikɨ, nu=juwáana aniáasi=jata.
Translated_Text: Her lover was the one who had made a hole in the fish trap, with the blunt end of his spear.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, nu=anɨɨ́kiaana iina muuti, “Muuti, saakaa kia=miíyaa?”
Translated_Text: Then he called to the agouti, “Agouti, what are you doing?”
She is calling out, “Juuuuu!”
Then he called to the young men.
Who is calling from there in the fallow garden?
I am carrying firewood (with a tumpline).

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́ta taárikɨ kaa aniita asáana iina n=arakíika=na, nu=raatikuraana sɨɨ́sanurika.
Translated_Text: Since his nephew was not a glutton, he drank a small quantity.

Primary_Text: Jaa na=anɨɨtɨ́ɨ naa, “Atɨja, jaa kí=mii iina aákuta.”
Translated_Text: Then he invited them, “Look here, I have now made the ayahuasca.”
Now he has made me angry.

Primary_Text: Kia=kamáraa iitíini, átiiji kiaá nuu aníruu.
Translated_Text: First you clear the vegetation, then you will fell the trees.
He was clearing (trees to make) his garden.

Primary_Text: Aámiikáaka kw=anítakura iina piyúuri, iyaamiaákuji nu=íriitakurá káami nɨɨku.
Translated_Text: Yesterday I felled (for) the currasow, because it got stuck up in the height (of the tree).

Primary_Text: Aniwa=íiku na=sákiiyaárikɨ nuu, iyaamiaákuji nu=miiyaárikɨ pɨyɨ́ɨni saakaaya, iipɨ nakusijiaárikɨ kaa taapɨ míini.
Translated_Text: For that they hated him, because he did all sorts of things that others didn’t know how to do.
He went towards him.
Then they brought it to their father.
In the morning he went (towards) there.
His wife took her basket to the garden.

Primary_Text: Tɨɨ kana=jíwɨɨtakiaakɨ́ nuu=na, átii=ji kana=aníkiaakɨ=wajá tuu Ikíitu=jina=ánuura nuu=jata jaa.
Translated_Text: From where we caught up with it (a riverboat), from there we indeed came to Iquitos with it.
He came to see his nephew.
See here, Iísuuja, I have come for you (i.e., to fight you).
You all are going for two years.
Only she knew what she had.
The only thing they ate was <siwɨɨka>.
Then they began to drink manioc beer.
That child touched the food.
Then he touched (something) inside his bag, that King Vulture.
Someone touched me on the waist.
Aa, a spear passed through me in my dream.
The jaguar did not catch me.

Primary_Text: Ánasa kia=miisakari kíija, kií kiaa ásaki; kaa kí=paajii kia=apɨráani.
Translated_Text: If you hurt me, I will eat you; I will not let you escape.
She left (some of) her food for her children to eat.
I left one tree (did not fell it, unlike all the others).
The sajino smells musky.

Primary_Text: Iina kaasi naasíija, mukwa nu=ápiitaa iyaamiaákuji taa mukuuja.
Translated_Text: The sajino meat smells rotten because it is rotten.

Primary_Text: Iina kaasi naasíija turiija, taarɨ́ɨja nu=ápiitaa.
Translated_Text: The smoked sajino meat smells delicious.

Primary_Text: Nu=jímuukiaakɨ=ná kuustáara=jinakuma iipɨ sɨɨsaramaajɨtáapɨ... nu=apiitániikiaakɨ=ná iinami=iíkumaji naawaaka.
Translated_Text: He stuck the three (demon minions) in a sack... and he hung them above the cooking fire.
Lots of masato was left over from the welcome celebration.
He won’t escape death, my husband.
I escaped from the jaguar eating me.
He is exploring that (area of) forest for game.

Primary_Text: Nu=apiyɨɨ́nɨɨmaa tíira, náaji jɨɨ́ta iina miikurá taana.
Translated_Text: He blazed a path there, like the other (man) did.

Primary_Text: Araa, jaa nu=jíwɨɨtakiaajá nuu, niwa=aákuji nu=anɨɨ́yaa.
Translated_Text: Aha, they (must have) have found her, and because of that they are calling.
We have also come to visit you, my fellow elder.
Don’t fight with your fellow women.

Primary_Text: Iiti ki=mɨ́jɨɨtaa kina=árata, náaji jɨɨ́ta kina=iíkii k=isákuji.
Translated_Text: I live well here, like you, as you live upriver of me.

Primary_Text: Anuu taárikɨ=na, iina mɨɨsaji takínuurikɨɨka, naa=yaa=na naajaá waarata kusiaamɨ, Saákisa=árata.
Translated_Text: She was, that little woman, likewise also tough just like Saákisa.

Primary_Text: Atii=ná=yaa ajapaka juríini=árata nikisáana nu=imaárɨɨkiaakɨ=ná iipɨ kaayaaka.
Translated_Text: Right then the wasp-like demons overwhelmed the people.
I saw a canoe like your canoe.
I saw over there several (tables) like this table.

Primary_Text: Kuuta ajapaka aratíina=jaa, na=imaárɨɨ tii amakɨ=jina.
Translated_Text: Perhaps the wasp-like things (created by a spell), they will overwhelm them there on the path.
He kept his word (promise).

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari=na na=aratiínɨɨ iina asáani siwɨɨka nuúkiika amáriyaana=na, jaa na=aratiínɨɨ na=siyaanɨ́ɨni.
Translated_Text: When they finished eating <siwɨɨka> for one year, then they completed their diet.
Their canoes weren’t sufficient (big enough) for them.
In order that it (a quantity of manioc beer) suffice for us, we can’t serve him any.
Let’s make its length equal with the other pole.

Primary_Text: Jaa nu=aratiínɨɨkura iina pɨ́=kaakɨ́ɨja iíkii p=ɨsákuji.
Translated_Text: He has now matched our Father who lives above us (because he was able to fly).
He comes singing along the way.
They are good, those (songs) that you sang.
In vain he scratched his skin.
That boy is paddling upriverwards, to the creek.
I forgot to visit my friend.
He forgot his machete.

Primary_Text: Kaa nu=aríwatɨɨyaárikɨ iina n=ani, iina nu=ijíwiitaárikɨ nuu.
Translated_Text: He didn’t obey his mother, that which she scolded him.

Primary_Text: Aríwatɨɨ kíija, iina kw=átuuyaa kiáaja, samáraataákwaa.
Translated_Text: Pay attention to me, that which I am avising you, and go rest.

Primary_Text: Jawáari kií kiaa aríwatɨɨ, jɨɨ́ta iina taa kíija, kusiaamɨ kíija.
Translated_Text: Afterwards I will believe you, (that) you are like me, brave and strong (like) me.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́ta=na nu=sikɨɨkuraaná iina sɨɨsaramaajɨtáami paatíina aaka=jina, iina nu=aruukiítakurá iina aaka=na, na=tuújiikuraaná iina aaka, na=tuújiikuraaná aaka wɨɨrɨ́ɨni, siuuu!
Translated_Text: As he threw the three pieces of balsa wood into the water (and) he blew on the water, they heard the water, they heard the water roar, shuuu!

Primary_Text: Kwaasɨja, kií kiaa saakɨɨ́nii nuúkiika kaaya, iina taárikɨ=na pisúuni=jina aruukiítaaja.
Translated_Text: OK, I am going to tell you a story about a person who was cured in ‘atinga’.
“Now we'll eat heron!” (she said)
“Now let’s eat, nephew.”

Primary_Text: Maasiáana niínakɨya kaa kí=makɨkurá suwaata; ásapɨ manánuukura kíija.
Translated_Text: Many nights I have not slept well (because) ants have bothered me.
OK, we’ll just have to trick you (back to being well).
The spear struck me a glancing blow.
They fed him game meat.
I aready fed them.
He kicked the shin of the yashingo.

Primary_Text: Iina pɨsɨkɨ nu=irijɨɨ́taa aaka=karikuma iyaamiaákuji nu=asiíkaa niíya=jina.
Translated_Text: The tapir is producing bubbles underwater because it is stepping on the ground (i.e., riverbed).
The rope-trigger of an ‘armadillo’ (trap), he stepped on it, at the creek.
This morning, I slipped and fell in the mud.
My grandmother is feeding her chickens.

Primary_Text: Ki=sájiri ásuuyaa nu=kaajiya kaakáraaja sakaáruuki turuuja=jata.
Translated_Text: My grandmother is feeding her chickens dried corn.
Thus it was that I yanked my foot away from it (the demonic stingray).

Primary_Text: Mjm, k=íita taárikɨ iiti iimɨɨ́raata iniyana=jina, atii taa kí=kutɨɨja kí=maaya, Elizabét.
Translated_Text: Mjm, my house was here, downriverwards of the bridge, there was where my daughter Elizabét was born.
He began to yell, and then he fainted.

Primary_Text: Átiiji, na=iriwɨɨkura tíira nɨ́yiti iyakíira nuu jaa. Atíira nu=iwɨɨ́rɨkura.
Translated_Text: So then, they brought him there to his daughter’s house. There he died.

Primary_Text: K=iíkwaakura asúraaja iríini=ánuura nasikuúra=ji; atiíra=ji kw=aniaakurá, kí=kuuraasuu miiyaákura.
Translated_Text: I would go to bring manioc from my garden; coming from there, my heart would palpitate (lit. would do).
They are going off one after the other along the path. (Note that motion is supplied by the associated motion suffix <-yaárɨɨ>.)
Here you go, uncle, it’s done (grilling) now.
Saákisa placed her feet (in fighting position) there.
OK, let’s try it, let’s begin to drink.

Primary_Text: Atii=na nu=átuukiaakɨ=ná iipɨ nu=aájiya, “Kí=jiwɨɨtaki nuúkiika iímina tíira, iímina kumaku.”
Translated_Text: So then she told her grandchildren, “I found a canoe there, an old canoe.”

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari kiaá manaja kuúkiki=na, pupuja kia=átuutaki.
Translated_Text: When you get pregnant, the pygmy owl will accuse (reveal) you.
I’m patching our fish trap that got holed.
For that reason they named it (the river) ‘Nɨɨkamúumu’.

Primary_Text: Nu=ɨɨ́yaaka, atií=yaa aákari=íira, na=ɨɨ́yaa iina nɨɨsina=na ‘maayitɨ́ɨsi’.
Translated_Text: Her name, to this day, they call that eagle ‘maayitɨ́ɨsi’.
They found an elevated area, a good elevated highland.
He climbed up to the high ground, on top of the ‘restinga’.

Primary_Text: Iina jɨɨ́timijaarikɨɨká tɨɨ aákusana nuu=jina, iina taana kaá tɨɨ aákusana, aájapaki tɨɨ nu=íniija nu=ɨɨjakúura.
Translated_Text: Some are red; others are not red, and do not have seeds inside them.
You remove the seeds from the centers (of the fruits).
“Yes,” the woman said to him.

Primary_Text: Pɨyɨ́ɨni iina ɨɨjɨɨ́jinakɨya irɨwɨ, suúkwaraki tɨɨ.
Translated_Text: All the planks’ centers are dirty.

Primary_Text: Taana kaaya iikiaárikɨ nu=isákujiita, taana iikiaárikɨ nu=isámajiita, taana iikiaárikɨ na=ɨɨjɨɨ́jina.
Translated_Text: One person lived a bit upriver of another, another lived a bit downriver of another, and another lived right between them.
That clay bowl is resting right in the center of the wooden table.
She is sitting between them.

Primary_Text: Iina=na nakɨ, iina máana iikiaárikɨ tii, waarata kaayaaka ɨɨjɨɨ́kujina, anuu taárikɨ=na siimana.
Translated_Text: The father, the elder who lived among his fellows, he was a shaman.
He is at the party.

Primary_Text: Kuukwaná tɨɨ k=ijúuti iíjinaji, tikiná tɨɨ kí=naajuútaaja iíjinaji sakumatáani.
Translated_Text: The point of my needle is sharp, however the point of my pencil is blunt.
The vulture is sitting at the tip (i.e., top) of the tree.
The man is standing at the end of the garden.

Primary_Text: Nu=kitɨrɨɨ niíya=jina karíini, nu=káriikiaaná nunamija=iíjinaji, nu=asapɨ́ɨni=íira iina kaaya, nu=káriitɨ́ɨni=íira naajaá nuu, atii nuú nuu=jina sikɨki náwɨɨta.
Translated_Text: He stopped looking at the ground, and looked directly at the sun, to fool the man, to make him look also, and then leap on him by surprise.
There is a lot of manioc beer.

Primary_Text: Kinaa kina=mɨra kutɨ́ɨ, átiiji imɨráani kaayaaka imɨráani iikiki maasiáana.
Translated_Text: You will bear children, and from that once again there will be many (people).
His house is downriver of my port.

Primary_Text: Iina waarata kusiaamɨ mɨɨsaji iikiaárikɨ káami Nɨɨkamúumu aájiku.
Translated_Text: The other brave woman like her lived upriver at the mouth of the Chambira River.

Primary_Text: Kí=saakii jaátaaraata=na maakatúuwa iikiaárikɨ=na pɨyɨ́ɨni maasiáana aakaka anákaka=jina: Takarnáaku, Anatimu, Nɨɨkamúumu, Muumúumu, Maasayuúmu=jina.
Translated_Text: I will recount how our ancestors lived at the headwaters of many rivers: the Nanay, Pintuyacu, Chambira, Momón and Mazán Rivers.

Primary_Text: Nuú kiaa jíwɨɨtaki iiti, nuú kiaa aámuu, iyaamiaákuji nuu náaji aátiki, “Jaa kia=iíkiki kí=majáana=jata.”
Translated_Text: If he finds you here, he will kill you, because he will say thus, “You have been with my woman.”
She had already taken a long time (i.e., been away checking their fishtrap).

Primary_Text: Átiiji=jaa, jɨɨ́ta kana=niíya=na, kanáaja tɨɨ naaraatá=yaa iina akúmari níiya iiku.
Translated_Text: Then, as (it is) our land, we are the very owners of the land upriver here.

Primary_Text: Nuu=jata na=sajiki nuu=iíkuku, pa pa pa.
Translated_Text: With it (a hatchet), they cut its surface, pa pa pa.

Primary_Text: Juu, mɨɨsaji nikisawɨɨ́kiaana nasi, tii nasi=iíkuma, natánaaja=waja pɨyɨ́ɨni suwáani asáani=íira jaa.
Translated_Text: Wow, the woman arrived to see the garden, there over the whole surface of the garden, all cultigens, all ready to eat already.
They went over there, along the path.

Primary_Text: Jaari=na iina maníini nu=nɨtɨmaakurá iina iniyana=iíkuma.
Translated_Text: Then the young man went running over the bridge.
He climbed right up the house post.

Primary_Text: Na=tuújiikiaaná naami=ji nu=saaki=iíkuma=ji, pak puu, pak puu, pak puu.
Translated_Text: They heard from downriver, from along the straight stretch of river, pak puu, pak puu, pak puu (the sound of someone paddling).

Primary_Text: Jaa nu=nu=kurika=iíkuku jiiniki náaji, sáa sáa sáa.
Translated_Text: He rubbed it (a shamanic powder) on his hands thus, saa saa saa (sound of rubbing).
He blew tobacco smoke on the surface of the balsawood (shafts), well magicked.

Primary_Text: Anuu=na anijíkɨrɨɨkuraaná nɨ́yini=íiku, iyaamiaákuji tipanɨɨri asakurá nuu.
Translated_Text: He had gotten angry due to his child, because the demonic stingray had eaten him.
It is your fault (lit. due to your doings), that you will be inundated.
If it (the light of the rainbow) falls on your body, it will burn you.
She is lying.
I can’t tell you a lie.

Primary_Text: Kí=nakarɨɨ́yaa kia=sanitáani, iyaamiaákuji jaari=na kí=samɨɨ́rɨrɨɨkiaaná kia=iíkwaami tuujíini, kiáaja taá=na kusiaamɨ=na.
Translated_Text: I want to test you, because I have become tired of hearing these rumors about you, that you are brave.

Primary_Text: Jaari=na nu=aátikiaaná nuu, “Jaarí tɨɨ k=iíkwaji, Saákisa.”
Translated_Text: So then she said, “That’s enough for me, Saákisa.”
Stop already, that enough for me!
I returned after getting my plantains.
I escaped death.
I grabbed it by the tail.

Primary_Text: Iyaamiaákuji na=muusisaárɨɨkari iina aasamu, jaari iina tipanɨɨri kásiitaki nuu, nu=titika=iíkwaji iiti, p=ánimɨ=iíkwaji.
Translated_Text: Because if they swam in creeks, then the demonic stingrays grabbed them, by the foot, by our heel.
She hand-strained some of her manioc beer mash.

Primary_Text: Jaa kí=miiyaárikɨ náaji amáriyáana, pɨyɨ́ɨni pɨ́=titika=iíkwaji.
Translated_Text: I was 20 years old (lit. all of our feet (and hands)).

Primary_Text: Aajaa, imɨɨ́tarɨɨkiaana=wajá iimi ariwáani, iimi kia=áriikwaki kia=aákɨsisaákari.
Translated_Text: OK, do those songs again that you sang while you were intoxicated (with ‘ayahuasca’)

Primary_Text: Atii na=asaárikɨ iina aámɨɨka íimɨ, iina asúraaja íimɨ.
Translated_Text: Then (when there was nothing else) they ate ‘airambo’ leaves and manioc leaves.

Primary_Text: Iina awásɨɨyɨ, nu=ímaa iina tiíra=akájinakuúraji amakɨ.
Translated_Text: The vinesnake is lying across that path over there.
Look! Those there are my sisters.

Primary_Text: Iina ánaka mɨɨsaji, pɨyɨ́ɨni nu=kajasi ijakuraaná, pɨyɨ́ɨni, iinawaja nu=kajasi, aájapaki.
Translated_Text: The woman’s head, all its hair had fallen off, all of it, no hair at all, there was none.

Primary_Text: Pɨyɨ́ɨni nu=iipɨ ásaki, iinawaja nuúkiika apɨrɨ́ɨni.
Translated_Text: It (a stingray monster) will eat all of them, not even one will escape.
We are never going to eat that fish!
I will never want you again.
He will never rise again (since he is dead).

Primary_Text: Kií=ta iiniíyaa kurɨ́ɨsi, niwa=aákuji kí=rimúsii nuu=jina.
Translated_Text: I mistook it for a Dusky Titi, so I shot it.
Here it is, that which you mistakenly think that I stole from you.
We believed erroneously, “She already arrived, in the afternoon.”
She is warming her little girl (against her body).

Primary_Text: Nu=káriiyaárikɨ=na iipɨ=jina taapɨ iitimɨra, iipɨ mɨra iikiaárikɨ=na.
Translated_Text: She would look at the other women who had children (lit. whose children existed).
We are going to roast it, for us to eat.

Primary_Text: Jaa nu=majáana aátiki, “Aákari ki=síratakwaa, ki=míini=íira itíniija.”
Translated_Text: Then his wife said, “Now I am going to go harvest (manioc) to make manioc beer.”
I would buy clothes with chickens for my children.

Primary_Text: Nu=miíyaa kuuta sakújaaja iina iíraana tiímaaka.
Translated_Text: Perhaps he has ‘piripiri’ for paca.

Primary_Text: Iina mɨɨsaji iitakaasi, kaa nu=jikátii jɨɨ́tikari nu=iíta=jina=ji.
Translated_Text: That ‘stay-at-home’ woman, she never leaves her house.

Primary_Text: Tii k=iíta=jina, maasiáana tákusi iitakaasi iíkii tii.
Translated_Text: There in my house, lots of house spiders live there.
She was here, she wasn’t there.
It’s this size (with gesture).

Primary_Text: Na=apárakuraana paápaaja titikáani=jina na=kánɨɨsi=jinakuma, juu, iitiina kánɨɨsi.
Translated_Text: They began to pile up fish in their net bag, wow, a bag like this (indicating large size with gesture).
That person is from here.

Primary_Text: Náaji kia=iíkumaa, kaa kia=iíkwakuma tiirɨɨ́raata, naa=kaa=jaa iitiíraata.
Translated_Text: Thus you will walk; don’t walk towards there, nor towards here.
The tapir fled along here (indicating a path).
A large ‘paiche’, like this (indicating its circumference with a gesture).

Primary_Text: Kiaá nuu ínaki tɨɨti taa iíwana kiaa=íira.
Translated_Text: You put it wherever is itchy.
There he left me, on the edge of the creek.
Her house is on the edge of the creek (upriver).

Primary_Text: Anɨɨtɨɨ́wɨɨ iipɨ p=árata ɨɨyáapɨ iíkii káami p=ɨsákuji.
Translated_Text: Go and invite our fellows who live there upriver of us.

Primary_Text: Kia=karíkuuyaákiaana, niaatíija, iyaamiaákuji=na kia=ijáki iina júuti.
Translated_Text: You are experiencing a bad omen, mother, because you stabbed the Tiger Heron.
It is loud (lit. loudly it is making a sound).
That’s how my father would scold and instruct us.

Primary_Text: Atii nu=ikaaniikuútakiaakɨ=na niíya=jina nuu, suwa ikaaniikuútaaja.
Translated_Text: Then he drove them (vertical poles for constructing a weir) into the creek bed (lit. the ground), well inserted
Yesterday my hand blistered because I burned myself.

Primary_Text: Iina aákuta, nu=ikaárikɨ kusi=jinakuma na=raríini=íira nuu.
Translated_Text: The ‘ayahuasca’ was standing inside the pot in order for them to drink it.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina nikisawɨɨ́kiaana samúkwaati ikaanúuja, juu, samúkwaati, aákusana samúkwaati.
Translated_Text: Right then he arrived and saw plantains piled up, wow, plantains, ripe plantains.
When she would eat, she would vomit.
She vomited blood, when she wanted to vomit.

Primary_Text: Jawáari=na nu=iikwaárikɨ=na tíira, tɨɨ nu=kusi imaárikɨ siiki=jina.
Translated_Text: Then he would go there, to where his cooking pot sat, in the ‘restinga’.

Primary_Text: Iina maayaarika nu=imakurá nuu, nu=imakurá iina kaimíitu.
Translated_Text: That little girl ate it, she ate the caimito.

Primary_Text: Jaa iina raatiki maayɨɨka nuu, nu=imaárɨɨ nuu.
Translated_Text: The little child had already drunk it, he had swallowed it (all).
They (the demonic stingrays) completely finished him off as I watched.
He beat him (in the fight).
He had a tumor (and was unable to walk).
Drunk, he was there nodding from side to side (while squatting).

Primary_Text: Iina aniita asáana, pɨyɨ́ɨni yaawɨ́ɨni=jina nu=imaákuuyaa nu=asásana.
Translated_Text: That glutton, every day he gulps down his food.
He fed his wife the fish caught in his fishtrap.

Primary_Text: Kaa=kija nu=nakusiaárikɨ náaji, “Kí=rimúsiija tɨɨ iina imátaa kw=ariíkuma.”
Translated_Text: But he (the tiger) didn’t know thus, “It’s my shotgun that rests on my shoulder.”

Primary_Text: Iiná tɨɨ nu=tiínaaja imátaa tii, kaa uumáana.
Translated_Text: That is his ‘tinaja’ (clay vessel) standing there, (it is) not large.
The vulture called to her again.
Give me some again (lit. repeat me).
Today I will go there (upriver) again.
Not having taken his medicine, he has gotten worse (more sick).
She put his fish on the smoking rack.
Well, where did my son-in-law leave you?
She came to leave it at her homestead.
He is pale (has pallor), because he has ‘vicio’.
The manioc beer mash is covered with flies.
The salt dissolved in the water.
That candle has completed melted.
This wild caimitillo (fruit) is ripening now.

Primary_Text: Anuu, iina=na mɨɨsaji taárikɨ=na kusiaamɨ, p=aátii mɨɨsaji kusiaamɨ, aájapaki waarata mɨɨsaji ípɨɨtaárikɨ=na nuu.
Translated_Text: As for her, the woman who was tough, what we call a tough woman, no other woman could strike her.
If you are going to drink, drink well, without fighting.
They are fighting there.
Neither do I fight with anyone, ever.
Bring along all your children.
They took my spirit (fotograph)!
He is walking haltingly because he is afraid.
The earthquake shook the earth.
I organized all of it (my house) already.
The man is standing by the side of the house.
She lay on her side.

Primary_Text: Iina n=akɨ anɨɨtɨɨ́kiaakɨ=ná iipɨ waarata ɨɨyáapɨ na=kajíini=íira iina mɨɨsaji irisiiti.
Translated_Text: Her father invited their people to perform the menarche celebration for the menstruated woman (i.e., who had recently menstruated for the first time).
I took hold of my fishing spear.
He carried only his <kwaakɨ́ɨna> (magic powder, in its gourd).

Primary_Text: Aajaa, kina=imɨɨ́takwaa wɨɨrɨɨtáani, “Jaa pɨyɨ́ɨni p=árata ɨɨyáapɨ irítakura aaka?”
Translated_Text: OK, go and ask again, “Have all of our fellow folk now gotten water (from the river)?”
When it has cooled, (then) you put it back to boil on the cooking fire.
I went upriver to the abandoned house.
I weeded around it (lit. its surrounding space).

Primary_Text: Anuu=na, nu=ikakuraaná aasamu isakijiíraji tíira, náaji.
Translated_Text: He stuck it (a stick to serve as crosspiece for a weir) there, directly across on the other side of the creek.
The people are standing in front of (i.e., obstructing access to) the woman.
The fence is around the house.
That medicine man, he is visiting a man who suffers from ‘asma’.
That tree branch re-injured my wound (when I bumped into it).
She turned into salt.

Primary_Text: Átiiji=na=jaa, kaa na=pariiyaárikɨ=na nuu aamúuni, iyaamiaákuji taárikɨ=na júura uumáana, iina mɨyaara itɨni.
Translated_Text: Then they couldn’t kill him, because he was really big, that transformed jaguar.
In the speech of the ancestors, it had become a transformed being.
He’s eating again (shortly after having just eaten).

Primary_Text: Kia=saákɨsaakari niwa, kaa kia=paájii kí=nikíini iwaárika.
Translated_Text: If you talk about this, you will never see me again.
She never had children again.
He never returned.
Soon they were moaning, “Jmm.”
Today I finished it off (a bottle of medicinal tonic).
Then the day dawned (lit. we experienced dawn), and she was saying, “Why are you unwell?”
It’s this size, like this here (indicating a garden).
It’s this size (indicating the interior of a saliently small house).
At that moment he lifted up his axe and went off.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iipɨ=na tuújiikiaaná muutúuru aaka=jinakuma=ji, sssrrr.
Translated_Text: Right then they heard a motor from downriver, sssrrr.

Primary_Text: Íyaa=na n=arakíika aátikuraaná nuu, “Ámaaja, pɨyɨ́ɨni pɨ́=kapii iina paápaaja?”
Translated_Text: At that point his nephew said, “Uncle, are we going to cook all this fish?”
At that moment he ran to her, toward here.

Primary_Text: Íyaa kaájapaa=ná=yaajaa, nu=jɨɨrɨɨkuraaná nu=juwáana, kuumi juwáana, nuúkiika nuu iíraana, nuúkiika iina iíraana, iina=ánuura nu=iíkwaa waarata mɨɨsaji.
Translated_Text: And verily, she took hold of her lance, two lances, one for her and one for the other woman to whom she was going.
Where is the lake edge?
The edge of my pot has broken.
They arrived at the edge of the creek.
She was lying on the edge of her palmwood floor.

Primary_Text: Iyaákari=yaa nu=kuúkirɨɨkuraaná pakana, náaji jɨɨ́ta arama púriija, jawáari=na nu=irikuraaná iina paatíina, iina nu=masɨɨ́kiaakɨ=ná nu=mɨra.
Translated_Text: When the achiote had become thick, like hand-strained mud, then he took the balsa wood which he had asked his sons for.
Then his mother-in-law would order him to clear it (a garden).

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na nuúkiika máana íyaakitakiaakɨ=ná nu=majáana, “Wiija, míi itíniija.”
Translated_Text: Then an old man ordered his wife, “Wife, make manioc beer.”
She is tired of her companion.
I have gotten tired of living in Iquitos.

Primary_Text: Nuúkiika kaaya iikiaárikɨ=na maakatúuwa iyákari, iina=na akuumiaárikɨ nuúkiika mɨɨsaji iítiijiina, pɨ́=kujímani.
Translated_Text: There was a man in the time of the ancestors, who got together with a woman from here, a companion of ours.

Primary_Text: Iina saáwiri, nu=iyikuuraánɨɨkura kíija pɨyɨ́ɨni pɨ́=kurika.
Translated_Text: This machete cost me ten (lit. all our hands) (soles).
We hurried, in order not to sleep in the forest.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, iina aana iyátarɨɨkiaakɨ́ iina iiyɨɨ, tsak, kabuuu, kabuuu, kabuuu.
Translated_Text: It turned out that the dolphin cut the fishing line, tsak (sound of line being cut), kabuuu, kabuuu, kabuuu (sound of it escaping; in this story, dolphins are actually people, and carry knives).

Primary_Text: Jaari iina doctor iyátakiaakɨ́ nuu=jina, sak, sak, sak.
Translated_Text: The doctor cut him, sak, sak, sak (sound of the doctor cutting his skin, as part of surgery)
From the upriver path they arrived here, at our place.

Primary_Text: Nu=miitɨɨ́kiaakɨ=na itíniija nuu, iina pɨ́=raatii iiti naajaa p=ɨ́yiki.
Translated_Text: She (the ‘sacharuna’) gave him manioc beer, that which we also drink here in our world.

Primary_Text: Iina saáwiri, nu=iyikúura tɨɨ pɨyɨ́ɨni pɨ́=kurika.
Translated_Text: The price of this machete is ten (lit. all our hands) (soles).

Primary_Text: Kaa na=pariikurá nuu=jata iyaamiaákuji nu=káriikura nuu=iyikúura.
Translated_Text: They could not defeat her because she defended herself.
Because I can’t defend myself...
Thanks to this person, my child did not drown.

Primary_Text: Nu=iyakúura iina señora, kí=nakúsii pɨyɨ́ɨni saakaaya iina nu=paájuuyaárikɨ kíija.
Translated_Text: Thanks to this lady, I know everything that she taught me.
He came out in his behalf (i.e. defended him).
“I will die on their behalf,” he said to his father.
With these (crosspieces) he tied them crosswise against the (vertical) poles, like so.
He stuck them into the ground (creek bed) against the (flow of the) water.

Primary_Text: Aniwa taa suuwami paajúuni: kaa na=kuúkikuma iyújusapɨ.
Translated_Text: This is good to teach: (that) they not become lazy people.
So he stayed on the Earth.
I remained an orphan.

Primary_Text: Káami kí=nakarɨɨ́yaa iina kí=nasi iyuutáani, pɨyɨ́ɨni tíira.
Translated_Text: There upriver (of us), I want to mark the perimeter my garden, all (that area) over there.

Primary_Text: K=iímina íyuuti tɨɨ saámina; kí=siiwíika íyuuti sakumatáani kumakú tɨɨ.
Translated_Text: The (bow) rope of my canoe is new, however the (fishing) line of my fishhook is old.
Now look, the handle of my pot has bent.
It has gotten a hole.

Primary_Text: Kutatáani=aákuji kíija, kaa makɨɨníita k=iíkii jaa.
Translated_Text: In the early morning (around 4am), I am no longer sleepy (i.e., I have become wakeful).

Primary_Text: Iina maaya, nu=jaámanakɨ́ɨ asúraaja=jata; iina taana maaya, nu=kɨ́ɨ paápaaja niíki=jata.
Translated_Text: That child choked on (too much) manioc; the other child choked on a fish bone.
Which is your manioc beer, my fellow?
Which song do you want?
She acquainted me with which (man) is her husband.
That’s it, absolutely all of us have water.
We have already drunk your manioc beer.
They took flight; and then they passed by.
She dumped out her chopped manioc, once it was well cooked.

Primary_Text: Nu=aatiaárikɨ=na iipɨ maniínikuuri raatiki jaari, “Kií kina átuu.”
Translated_Text: He said to the youths who had drunk, “I will now counsel you.”
Who wants to go with me?

Primary_Text: Átiiji=na, nu=iíkikiaakɨ=na jɨɨ́timi amáriyaana iina=jata mɨɨsaji.
