Perhaps she slept a little further away.

Primary_Text: Iina aátikiaakɨ́ waarata tawɨ nuu, “Kia=pariíyaa kuuta k=ináani káami k=íyiku, Nɨɨkamúumu anáka=jina?”
Translated_Text: The other mestizo said to him, “Can you perhaps take me upriver to my place, in the headwaters of the Chambira river?”

Primary_Text: Pɨyɨ́ɨni kuuwaa, sikiáaja, mɨyaara, iina nu=nikiaárikɨ nu=aámuuyaárikɨ nuu.
Translated_Text: All game animals, deer, jaguars, what she saw, she killed.

Primary_Text: Aajaa, kií=tɨ=jaa kiaa=jata iikwaárɨɨkiáaja, kí=nikíini=íira iipɨ kaayaaka iina miitɨɨ́yaa kiáaja iina kuuwaa turiija.
Translated_Text: Well then, I’d better go with you, so I can see these people who give you smoked meat.

Primary_Text: Naa=kaa jaa kia=aátamajati=jata, saakaa=aákuji kiaa kiaa aátamajati kuwasikí=waja?
Translated_Text: And not with your sister either; why would you argue with your sister?
He (a shaman’s spirit reincarnated as a jaguar) spoke exactly like they spoke.

Primary_Text: Kaa kia=nakusisaákari iipɨ=jata kuwasíini kaayaaka, kaa na=paájii náaji nakusíini, saakaaya taa kia=saminiijúuni.
Translated_Text: If you don’t know how to talk to the people, then they won’t know what your thoughts are.
I made it wider.

Primary_Text: Iina náana, tíira nu=ímaa, kwaata nu=nikísaa.
Translated_Text: The treetrunk is over there (and) it is clearly visible.
She sees clearly.
My garden needs to be weeded.
I need to go to Iquitos.
I didn’t lack meat.
I lack two pots.

Primary_Text: Iina maaya, anuu taa júura maánuurika pɨyɨ́ɨni iipɨ=jinaji mɨrajaarika.
Translated_Text: That child is the oldest of all the children.
That child caused me to make an error in (my) weaving.
I disabled the Paca with (my) shotgun.

Primary_Text: Atii=na na=tiitakiaakɨ=ná iina amakɨ, na=jíwɨɨtakiaakɨ=ná, juu, maasiáana nasi, iitaka=jina.
Translated_Text: Then the followed the path and they encountered, wow, many ‘chacras’ and a settlement.

Primary_Text: Nu=imɨɨ́tarɨɨ kutɨtɨ́ɨni, nu=imɨɨ́takwaa síratáani waarata iitimɨra=jata, maasiáapɨ.
Translated_Text: Then it dawned again, and she harvested manioc again with her fellow women, many (of them).
The ‘puquiador’ frogs shoo the locusts away from their corn (fields).

Primary_Text: Iina maayaarika, nu=imákura nuu, imákura iina kaimíitu.
Translated_Text: That little girl ate it, she ate the caimito(s).

Primary_Text: Kíija, k=iikiaárikɨ kí=maayaarika Kuyɨɨsiyuúmu=jina; akami kí=kumɨkiáakɨ.
Translated_Text: I, in my childhood, I lived on ‘Pava Quebrada’; there I grew up.
I already went and slept there (upriver).
We are going to go hunting/fishing (lit. sleep).

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari taa suwáani, nu=makɨki kuumi yaawɨ́ɨni=na, wáari kia=puúrii nuu.
Translated_Text: When it is ready, when it has sat fermenting for two days, then you hand-strain it.
She was thinking thus, “Why did I dream thus?”
Last month I dreamt about my brother.

Primary_Text: Kaa kiaá=tɨ iníkarɨɨ, kia=kúwaaja ɨ́tɨ kiaa átuukiáana, kií=tɨ kiaa aámuu kia=makɨɨna.
Translated_Text: If you had not woken up, your heart (lit. liver) would have told you that I would kill you in your sleep.
In my sleep, the recruiters put me inside the boat.

Primary_Text: Iina ikwani, nu=sanitɨ́ɨ nuu, iyaamiaákuji nu=manánuuyaa iipɨ kaayaaka.
Translated_Text: That man made him prove himself (by giving him a punch), because he (always) harrasses people.
It’s just that my vision that is bothering me.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, jaari iina aníkiaakɨ=ná ikwani nu=mananúuni=ánuura imɨráani.
Translated_Text: So, they say, soon that man approached to harrass her again.
His mother-in-law said to him, “Son-in-law, go and tie up our (bundle of) manioc stalks.”

Primary_Text: Aámiikáaka, jɨɨ́tikari Vidal siwaánɨrɨɨkura=ná, nu=masɨɨkurá naamɨ taniija.
Translated_Text: Yesterday, when Vidal arrived, he bought thatch (lit. woven leaves).

Primary_Text: Ki=sájiri, nu=masɨɨkura kíija kuuwaa kí=miitɨ́ɨni=íira nuu.
Translated_Text: My grandmother asked me to give her game meat.
Her daughter received the ‘piripiri’ from her.
What is happening to you, woman?
I have a (hafted) axe.
I had three illnesses.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari nu=miiyaárikɨ seis meses=na, wáari kana=iriaárɨɨkiaakɨ́ Yarinacocha=jina nuu.
Translated_Text: When she was six months old, then we brought her to Yarinacocha.

Primary_Text: Iipɨ maakatúuwa, na=míini taárikɨ kuuwaa aamúuni juwaána=jata.
Translated_Text: The (our) ancestors, their custom was to kill game with spears.

Primary_Text: Kaá tɨɨ ki=míini! Kina=míini=íiku kinaá tikitaki.
Translated_Text: It is not my fault! It is your fault that you’ll be inundated.
Just day by day I endured that sickness.
He gave it to his mother.
They give me smoked (meat).
Iísuuja was in her hammock.
The day is overcast.
Something dark was already visible, approaching under water.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́ta=na na=makɨkiaakɨ=ná tii iina=siriku na=kaakɨ́ɨja aákɨsiija=na, atii=na na=mɨ́rɨɨkiaákɨ=na.
Translated_Text: Since they slept by the side of their father while drunk, there they got pregnant.
He squeezed the ant between his finger and thumb to kill it.
He squeezed my arm.

Primary_Text: Kwaaki, kwaaki, náana murútasɨɨja tɨɨ na=ipúruuyaárikɨ.
Translated_Text: Open space, open space, (all the) trees knocked over where there were fighting.
They dug a hole in the ground and buried him.
How is that woman related to you?

Primary_Text: Kaa nu=paájii jɨɨ́taaraa míini, iyaamiaákuji nu=kɨɨrɨɨyaárikɨ naajaá iina tipanɨɨri.
Translated_Text: He couldn’t do anything, because he also feared the demonic stingray.

Primary_Text: Jaa Saákisa naajáaja, nu=niíkirɨɨkiaaná nu=juwáana, nu=karíini=íira nuu=kaanaji.
Translated_Text: Saákisa also, she had raised her spear to defend herself.
My father was tired also.
In that way I lived with my husband.

Primary_Text: Kaa uumáana, iitinuúrika samaku náaji, suwáani samaku pɨ́=nikii.
Translated_Text: Not big, a little gourd versel like this (gesture indicating a diameter of 15cm), a gourd we see (as) very nice.

Primary_Text: N=aátikiaakɨ=ná náaji, “Iina taa=na p=ɨɨ́yaasúuja kɨɨ́wasiija, iina iíkii iiti...”
Translated_Text: They said thus, “This is the soul of our grandfather, that which is here...”
Let’s keep an eye on our barbasco downriver, and from there downriver we will return.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari nu=kuukiaárikɨ niínaki=na, niínama naami na=íyama.
Translated_Text: When it became night, it was very dark inside their house.
He put it on a leaf.
Go bathe, to put your body in order (he said).

Primary_Text: Iina k=itíniija, nu=náani iíkii tíira k=iitakúura.
Translated_Text: The remainder (or greater part) of my manioc beer is at my house.
The mother is bathing her daughter in the creek.
They went to bathe in the creek.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, iina=jata paatíina, iina=iíkuku=na nu=naaraájuukiaakɨ=ná, nu=iíkwakiaakɨ=ná iipɨ sanitáani=ánuura nu=kujímaka iwárɨkapɨ.
Translated_Text: Then, with that (piece of) balsa wood on which he had performed the ritual, he went to test the bodies of his dead companions (i.e., to see what type of witchcraft had killed them).

Primary_Text: Naaraata=na iina iikiaárikɨ=na ikwani, pɨyɨ́ɨni yaawɨɨ́ni=jina, náaji paápaaja kasiraáni=jata, tasikɨɨ́ni=jata.
Translated_Text: Thus the man lived in this way every day, catching fish with his fish trap.

Primary_Text: Náaji jɨɨ́ta kia=namikurá iina nakarɨ́ɨni ikwani=na, naaraata kiaá nuu nakarɨɨ́=kiyaa pɨyɨ́ɨni yaawɨ́ɨni.
Translated_Text: Thus, since you have begun to love this man, in this same way you will love him forever.
Little by little I got used to traveling by plane.
I will get better little by little, perhaps.
That is just the way I am.
I want achiote.
I want to clear my garden.
I also want to eat plantains.
We want you to go and visit him.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, nu=aátikiaakɨ náaji, “Kí=nakarɨɨ́yaa kia=nikíini=íira kí=kaakɨɨ́jawaaka.”
Translated_Text: Then she said to him, “I want you to see my parents.”

Primary_Text: Nu=tuújiiyaa, nu=nakarɨ́ɨ=na pɨ́=kuwasíini iina señorita, Ikíitu jinaana.
Translated_Text: She was listening, and the young woman from Iquitos liked our language (she said).
He loved those who were poor.
I almost drowned.

Primary_Text: Jaa kí=nakusiaárikɨ naajaá sɨɨsaárika tawɨ kuwasíini.
Translated_Text: By then I also knew a little Spanish.
How we would like to know that (i.e., how the jaguar died)!
He also knew how to play flutes.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari nuúkiika iwɨɨriáana iíkii=na, jɨɨ́tikari nu=nawɨyini puwaájɨɨ=na, jaa kana=nakúsii náaji, “Aákari=na kaa iina apɨ́rɨɨyaa iwarɨ́ɨni pɨ́=kujímani.”
Translated_Text: When there is a sick person, and when his spirit has whistled, then we know, “Now our companion will not escape death.”
I’m already feeling the pain of the snake (bite).

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari=na iina nakusirɨɨkuraaná mɨyaara náaji, “Jaa k=iwɨɨ́rii,” jawáari=na nu=nɨtɨmaakuraana nuúkiika náana=ánuura, náaji jɨɨ́ta iina náana, uumáana.
Translated_Text: When the tiger realized, “I’m dying,” he ran towards a tree, a tree like this one, large.
You know, uncle, the turtle has already escaped.

Primary_Text: Iina nu=nawɨyini, nu=nawɨyini, nu=miitɨɨkuraaná nu=nakusíini nuu.
Translated_Text: That spirit of his, his spirit, he gave it his wisdom.
He showed me his canoe.
She acquainted me (with the place) there where she lives.
She introduced me to her husband.
The ayahuasca is affecting me strongly.

Primary_Text: Naami=na pɨ́=karikuma, iiti tɨɨ p=ɨɨ́kii iina=jina níiya, naami pɨ́=karikuma, naa=nami=na taami iita, taapɨ kaaya iíkii, náaji jɨɨ́ta p=ɨɨ́kii iiti.
Translated_Text: Below, under us, here where we live on this earth, below, under us, down there, there are also other houses and other people, like those that are here.

Primary_Text: Kaa waarata ɨɨyáana námiisaákari nuu iina itíniija, kaa nu=paajiaárikɨ jɨɨ́tikari pɨyɨ́ɨni.
Translated_Text: If his fellows had not served him back that manioc beer, it would never have run out.
My fellow, I am going to serve (manioc beer) back to you (polite form).

Primary_Text: Jawáari=na=jaa, nu=aátikiaakɨ=ná, “Kaa aatiáana kina=akúmariwaaka iyikúura namíini kináaja, iipɨ iíkwaa amakɨ=jina, kina=aamúuni kaániwaaka.”
Translated_Text: Then indeed, he said, “May it be that you return the blows for your masters, to those who are going on the path after killing you.”
He is eating only meat.

Primary_Text: Pɨyɨ́ɨni yaawɨɨ́ni=jina, nu=ásaa namíiku iina kuuwaa.
Translated_Text: Every day, he eats meat alone (with no manioc).

Primary_Text: Nu=nikitɨɨkiaakɨ́ namíini nuu tii tɨɨ nu=iikiaárikɨ, nuúkiika ikwaniáasi=jina=na.
Translated_Text: First she showed him there (the place) where she lived, in a ‘supay chacra’.
He was her first husband.
You test me first.

Primary_Text: Kí=namija ajakuúsikura naajáaja, iyaamiaákuji kw=aamɨ́yaakii nakijina irákana tíkii kí=namija=jina.
Translated_Text: My sight has deteriorated too, because I walk in the forest and the ‘pucacuro’ ants fall in my eyes.

Primary_Text: Nu=namija tɨ=kijá tii aaka=jina, tɨɨ iina jimátii samuu.
Translated_Text: But his gaze was (directed) there to the water, where the ‘paiche’ was going to emerge.

Primary_Text: Nu=apárakiaakɨ=na niíya=jina muráani=jina, nu=iwáani=íira namíjiita, níiya karikumaji.
Translated_Text: It (the armadillo) began to dig in the earth, to go to the other side, under the earth.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari taa pɨyɨ́ɨni nataaja nuu=na, atii=ji kia=nátaa katija, kia=nátaa minati, kia=nátaa uumaarii.
Translated_Text: When the whole thing is planted (with manioc), then you plant ‘sachapapa’, you plant pineapples, you plant ‘umarí’.

Primary_Text: Naajaa jɨɨ́ta na=nataárikɨ nasi=na, na=maayaasiaárikɨ waarata iitimɨra=jata.
Translated_Text: Also as they planted garden, they joked with other women.

Primary_Text: Kí=saakɨɨ́niiyaa kiáaja nuúkiika saakɨ́ɨni, iimi kí=nakúsii sɨɨsaárika, jɨɨ́taaraata k=íyaasuújuusana saakɨɨ́niiyaárikɨ kíija, Irisiuu nawɨɨ́tana, anúuja.
Translated_Text: I will tell you a story, which I know a little, as my late grandfather told it to me, the late Eliseo, him.
I raised my grandchildren with my work, with their deceased grandfather.

Primary_Text: Aniwa=aákuji taa iipɨ maakatuúwawaaka, iipɨ miiyaárikɨ na=mɨra sɨɨ́sanurika=na, na=naájuuyaárikɨ nɨ́siija=jata nu=mɨra najika=iíjinaji, kaa nu=iríini=íira nu=nawɨyini.
Translated_Text: That is why the ancestors who had small children marked the tips of their noses with charcoal, so that she would not take their spirits.
They took your photograph in order to bring it to Iquitos.
I saw Yenny pinching my back.
His grandmother, my daughter, she jumped over on top of them.
He held up his axe (as) he looked around.
I went upriver along the path.

Primary_Text: Ki=maákata apárakuraaná mɨyɨkɨ́ɨni=jina niíkuma nɨtɨ́ɨni=jata, inárɨɨja.
Translated_Text: My father began to return along the path, running scared.

Primary_Text: Na=juúkurɨɨkiaakɨ=na niíya=jina, káami=ji, nɨɨku=ji, tɨɨ na=ɨɨyaárikɨ.
Translated_Text: They came down to the earth from above, from up high, where they were flying.
This (lit. here) is its height (with gesture).
He didn’t fall on the ground.
OK, we’ll run away to the end of the world.
It is noon.

Primary_Text: Nijápɨɨkí=yaa ikiítuwaaka na=iíkikiaakɨ=na tíira, tɨɨ na=ɨɨ́kiaakɨ Ikíitu=jina.
Translated_Text: Only the Ikíitu (people) lived there, where they (later) gave the name of Iquitos.
I want to talk to you briefly.
It is a great river, and they were afraid when they saw it.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, na=nikiíkiaana niíkuma=ji aniáapɨ, pɨyɨ́ɨni na=ániitaaja=jata.
Translated_Text: Then they see them coming from the path, all with their loads.

Primary_Text: Tɨɨti=tɨ iina aaka nikikiáaja, aájapaki aaka?
Translated_Text: Where would they find water, (since) there is no water (anymore)?
I am going to check on our fish trap.
Oh, child, from where did you appear?
Its appearance is like this.

Primary_Text: Iina nukwáana, nu=nikisatɨ́ɨ iina kaakáraaja iina nu=nawatájuukura.
Translated_Text: The thief revealed the chicken he had hidden away.

Primary_Text: Iina kaaya, nu=nikitɨ́ɨ nu=muutúuru saámina nu=isɨ́ɨku.
Translated_Text: The person showed his new motor to his friend.
It became afternoon and nothing (Agucha didn’t return).

Primary_Text: Atiiji=jaa, ninɨ́ɨni=aákuji, jɨɨ́ta kumaku kíija=na, kí=sɨɨmɨɨ́sii ninɨ́ɨni=aákuji.
Translated_Text: After that, in the afternon, since I am old, I feel cold in the afternoon.

Primary_Text: Jaa nunamija iwɨɨ́tarɨɨ tíira jaa, ninɨ́ɨni=aákuji kuúkirɨɨ.
Translated_Text: The sun is low in the sky, it is the afternoon.

Primary_Text: Náaji jɨɨ́ta p=ɨɨ́kii aákari, náaji yaawɨ́ɨni nínɨɨtaa.
Translated_Text: As we are now, thus the day became dark.
It became dark like (as if it were) the afternoon.

Primary_Text: Jaa pɨ́=raatiki iina yaawɨ́ɨni, jaa pɨ=nínɨɨtaa, jaarí tɨɨ niínaki pɨ́ɨja.
Translated_Text: We have drunk all day, night has fallen on us, (and) we are already in nighttime.
He shook with fear.
After the rain, we’ll go to the garden.
After eating, I will go bathe.
My deceased father ran off behind it (the tapir).
He (Jesus) watched from behind him (as) he went off to his residence.
He is palid.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari kia=niyaákimaa, náaji kiaá kia=níyaaka=jata tarawaájuu.
Translated_Text: When you get a husband, thus you will work with your husband.
One whole month passed us by (waiting for her to call).
We’ll search there for a (little bird), any old, little bird.
She alone, my mother, cared for us.

Primary_Text: Nuúrika nu=asɨɨyaárikɨ kíija, jɨɨ́tikari taárikɨ maaya kíija.
Translated_Text: Only this did my father feed me when I was a child.
I only saw that he fell into the water.
They fertilized the bases of the sugarcane, so it would grow well.
We got along (accustomed) well with him.
He probably won’t be able to catch me.
Oh, you won’t die, aunt.
He learned to read.
Go learn over there where he is calling you.
They taught us their languages.

Primary_Text: Pɨɨ́ naa paájuu nasi míini, kuuwaa paníini naki=jina, paápaaja paníini aaka=jina.
Translated_Text: We will teach them to make gardens, to seek out game in the forest, to seek out fish in the waters.

Primary_Text: Atíira na=paájuukiaakɨ kanáaja jaátaaraata taá soldado kuwíini=na, jaátaaraata taá pɨɨ p=ɨyɨkúura kárii aamuúkujina, pɨyɨ́ɨni saakaaya.
Translated_Text: There they taught us how to be soldiers, how we could look after ourselves during wartime, and everything.

Primary_Text: Atii nu=paájuuyaárikɨ kíija, “Iiná tɨɨ náaji, iiná tɨɨ náaji, iiná tɨɨ náaji.”
Translated_Text: There he taught me, “This is thus, this is thus, this is thus.”
For washing his clothes, he would pay us.
She lives peacefully.
The rain is falling heavily.

Primary_Text: Nu=wɨɨrɨɨ́takiaakɨ=ná iipɨ nu=kaayaaka, “Tɨɨti pɨ́=pariíyaa p=ɨ́yɨki míini, p=ɨwíini=íira tii?”
Translated_Text: He asked his people, “Where can we make our place (settlement), in order to live there?”

Primary_Text: Na=inaárikɨ=na aasamu=akájinakuúraji na=iníyana, náana, na=paríini=íira iniyáani aasamu.
Translated_Text: They put a bridge across the creek, a tree (trunk), so that they could cross the creek.
You’ll never be able to equal me (in fighting).

Primary_Text: Iyaamiaákuji kíija, kaa kia=paájii k=ɨ́ɨni paríini.
Translated_Text: Because as for me, you can’t match my flight (said the macaw).
Do you eat plantains?

Primary_Text: Kíija, jɨɨ́tikari kw=ákɨsii=na, aájapaki kí=paríini kuwasíini kia=íyima.
Translated_Text: I, when I am drunk, I don’t argue at your place.
He finished eating.
When they finished constructing their canoes, they left.
I have finished my clearing (i.e., finished clearing a particular patch of land intended for a garden).

Primary_Text: Náaji iipɨ=na pɨɨkakiaakɨ=na=waja iina itíniija , iipɨ námiiyaárikɨ nuu.
Translated_Text: Thus they finished off the manioc beer, those who had made him drink of it.
We alone will work (lit. do our doings).
I played soccer there in the patio (yard).
Then he saw his ex-wife.

Primary_Text: Náaji kí=niaatíija saakɨɨ́niiyaárikɨ kíija, “Jɨɨ́tikari taa=na manaja=na mɨɨsaji, pupuja tikiíkiaana iita=jinakuma.”
Translated_Text: That’s what my mother would tell me, “When a woman is pregnant, the pygmy owl enters inside the house.”
When it is rainy, that there is a muddy area.
Her head hurts.
Her foot hurts her.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́ta nu=riníkiinɨɨyaárikɨ náaji, iina juwáana jimatɨrɨɨkiaakɨ náaji iiti=ji nuu=íira.
Translated_Text: Because he was thrashing about, the lance came out like from here (gesturing), through him.
This tree has a bend in it (lit. stands crooked).
They cut this path crooked.

Primary_Text: N=awákukwa taárikɨ=na saana, náaji jɨɨ́ta pɨ́=nikii káaji awákukwa, kuukwami.
Translated_Text: Its claws were long, like we see claws of a sloth, sharp.

Primary_Text: Atii=na nu=aátikuraaná nuu, “Saakaa kia=nakarɨɨ́yaa kia=nasi=jina natáani?”
Translated_Text: And then he said to him, “What do you want to plant in your garden?”
He asked him, “What are you doing here?”

Primary_Text: Kaa kí=nakúsii saakaa=jata kií nuu ampiísii.
Translated_Text: I don’t know with what I will cure him.

Primary_Text: Kw=átuuyaa kiáaja, wíija, aákari saakaa aárɨɨyaa kíija, sɨɨ́sana makɨ́ɨni kí=miiyaa.
Translated_Text: I tell you, wife, today something is going to happen to me, (because) I have (just had) a bad dream.
I don’t want to know anything.
Why do you talk thus, husband?
Why have you come?
He didn’t find anything, nothing.

Primary_Text: Pɨɨ́ naa paájuu saakaaya míini, iina kwarɨɨ́niiyaa pɨ́ɨja.
Translated_Text: We will teach them to do (good) things, that which we lack.
I had everything there in the forest.
Now I’ll tell the story of the vulture with the macaw.
He talked with God (lit. our paternal uncle), with our Father.

Primary_Text: Náaji taárikɨ=na iina saakɨ́ɨni akíraja niyini.
Translated_Text: Thus was the story of the son of the wind.
I am going to tell you a story.

Primary_Text: Nu=saakɨɨ́niiyaárikɨ kíija jɨɨ́taaraata=na kana=maakatúuwa iikiaárikɨ=na iina=jina aaka, Anatimu, Nɨɨkamúumu.
Translated_Text: He told me how our ancestors lived on the Pintuyacu and Chambira Rivers.

Primary_Text: Kw=aníriti saakɨɨ́niiyaárikɨ kanáaja, “Máaya, tawɨya siwaánɨki iiti p=ɨ́ɨta=jina.”
Translated_Text: My maternal aunt related to us, “Child, mestizos arrived here in our house.”

Primary_Text: Kií kiaa saakɨɨ́nii nuúkiika mɨɨsaji iina taárikɨ=na kusiaamɨ.
Translated_Text: I’m going to tell you of a woman who was, they say, brave.

Primary_Text: Aákari kanáaja, kana=tuújii kia=ariwáani, saámina kia=ariwáani.
Translated_Text: Now we, we have heard your song, your new song.
I made this paddle recently.
Now we have heard your song for the first time.

Primary_Text: Kaa uumáana náana, náaji iitinuurika náana, náaji saana, nuúkiika námati nu=saana.
Translated_Text: Not thick sticks, (instead, slender) sticks like this, (and) long like this, one arm in length.

Primary_Text: Nikákiika=na imɨráani, kaa saaniitá=yaajaa, imɨráani na=tuújiiyaa aaka, siuu.
Translated_Text: Shortly again, not a long time at all, again they heard the water, shoo.

Primary_Text: Sɨɨ́sanurika aaka kinaa saátarɨɨ nami samaku=jina.
Translated_Text: Pour out a little bit of water there into the gourd.
Yesterday his canoe capsized.
To weave a hammock, (first) you cut the ‘chambira’ fiber.
Then he began to cut up the tapir.

Primary_Text: Nu=pɨɨkarɨɨkurá nu=tanakíini, jawáari=na nu=apárakuraaná naamɨ sajiitáani=jina, niraasi íimɨ.
Translated_Text: He had finished building the fence, and afterward he began to cut leaves, ‘shapaja’ leaves.

Primary_Text: N=arakíika iíkwakuraaná tíira, nu=sakátarɨɨkuraaná iina náana nu=animɨ=jina.
Translated_Text: His nephew went over there and went around the buttress roots of the tree.

Primary_Text: “Iiná=yaa kia=manánuu kíija, sákija, jaa kw=aámuu kiáaja,” ki=maákata aátikiaakɨ́ nuu.
Translated_Text: “For that which you were hassling me, I’ve killed you, and it serves you right,” my father said (to the jaguar).
He, on the other hand, was a bad person (in contrast to the good person just mentioned).
I rested yesterday.
Why is our fishtrap constantly developing holes?
So then the vulture began to tire.
He is checking it over, “Where, where did it get a hole?”

Primary_Text: Tiíra=na, na=saminiíjuuyaa, “Jɨɨ́taaraata iina ɨɨyaaráaja, p=árata kaaya?”
Translated_Text: There they were thinking, “How can someone like us fly?”
Thus they kept thinking that.
Don’t think about, when you are sick, your work.
Think about getting well.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, iina kaaya nu=saminiíjuukiaakɨ=ná iina nu=ariwáani, iina ariwáani makwaati.
Translated_Text: Then the man imitated the song, the song of the frog.

Primary_Text: Jaa nu=saniki nuu, iina paápaaja, suwáani.
Translated_Text: He tried it, the fish, and it was good.

Primary_Text: Pɨ́=sanítaa nu=natáani iiti pɨ=niíya=jina, pɨ́=nikíini=íira nu=kumɨsaákari.
Translated_Text: We will try planting here in our land, to see if it grows.

Primary_Text: Aákari kí=sanitaákiaana iina Iísuuja, iina iíkwaami ki=tuújiiyaa, kusiaamɨ taa=na Iísuuja=na.
Translated_Text: Now I am going to test this Iísuuja, for all the gossip I hear (of her), that Iísuuja is brave.
They began to keep track of the days (indicating with fingers), “They left on this one (day).”

Primary_Text: Jaa nu=sanitaki nuu, sɨɨsaramaajɨtáami námati nu=miíyaa.
Translated_Text: She already measured it, and it is three arms (in length).
She had me try her peach palm fruit brew.

Primary_Text: Kí=saakɨɨ́niiyaa kináaja jɨɨ́taaraata kw=aníriti sapiraákɨɨkiaakɨ́ nu=kaajiya=níwaji mɨyaaraa.
Translated_Text: I will tell you all how my aunt got lost following her dogs.
His headache is diminishing.

Primary_Text: Anuu, nu=sataakɨɨtɨɨyaakurá kanáaja aámiikáaka=na, juúmana=jaa iina maaya.
Translated_Text: She made us really laugh yesterday, (because) that child was very amusing.
They laughed at my father.

Primary_Text: Jaa náaji yaawɨ́ɨni na=ínaki sakɨ́ɨka, iina=jina, na=imɨɨ́takwaa síratáani siaakuruusíini=íira.
Translated_Text: The manioc beer mash had been set (to ferment) for three days (indicated with fingers), and in that (i.e., the fourth day), they again harvested (manioc), to mix it in (to the manioc beer mash).
No, you’re going to bite me.
The tree was well bitten (i.e., had deep teeth marks).

Primary_Text: Nu=iríkiaakɨ=na pɨyɨ́ɨni iipɨ siimaka iipɨ taárikɨ=na iwárɨkapɨ tii.
Translated_Text: He took all of the magic of all the dead there.

Primary_Text: Iina maaya, nu=siímɨki nu=kusi iijuútaaja aaka=karikuma.
Translated_Text: The child dove under the water for his pot lid.
The child is diving under the water.
There is cold in my bones.
I put it in cold water.

Primary_Text: Sɨɨmɨɨ́tiki tii nu=amákɨjina tɨɨ nuú=ta imátaa.
Translated_Text: There is a cool spot there in the place where he was lying.
With that, the dogs were about to bite at her.

Primary_Text: Nu=natakura siípakɨya nuu, kaa nu=mananúuni=íira iina taana.
Translated_Text: She planted them far from one another, so that they would not bother (i.e., obstruct) each other.

Primary_Text: Saakaa=íira k=imatɨɨkura sɨɨ́sa iina kaaya kuwasiitaakura kíija, íyaa nuu=jaa pɨ́=kaakɨ́ɨja niyini?
Translated_Text: Why did I respond badly to that person who was conversing with me, since he is the son of our father?
I had (lit. have) a bad dream.

Primary_Text: Iina kw=átuu kiáaja, íyaa sɨɨ́sana=jaa, iina p=ásamaa taariki.
Translated_Text: I told you, they were bad (i.e., too small), what we ate in morning.

Primary_Text: Kia=kuukisaákari sɨɨ́sana kaaya, kia=majáana kiaa sikɨɨ.
Translated_Text: If you are a bad-tempered person, your wife will leave you.

Primary_Text: Júura sɨɨ́sana kuúkii jaa, maasiáana iyásiika.
Translated_Text: It has gotten very weedy, lots of grass.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iipɨ=na, na=jíwɨɨtakiaakɨ=na nuúkiika mɨyaara sɨɨ́sanurikɨɨka=na.
Translated_Text: Then and there they found a small jaguar.
The were drunk, they were slightly drunk.

Primary_Text: Kinaa inaánii sɨɨsaárika aaka kíija=na, kaa uumáata.
Translated_Text: Put a little bit of water (in it) for me, not a lot.
They rarely pushed off to go in the middle of the river.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari taa sɨɨ́saki, kaa kia=paájii iyarákata síratáani.
Translated_Text: When it (the garden) is overgrown, you can’t harvest manioc quickly.

Primary_Text: Iina suwáani kaaya, kaa nu=sɨɨ́samiítaa nu=asásana.
Translated_Text: A good person isn’t stingy (miserly) with his food.

Primary_Text: Sɨɨsaramaajɨtáapɨ kaayaaka, sɨɨsaramaajɨtáapɨ aátamajaniwaaka=na, na=raatikiaakɨ=ná iina saasasíkwaa iíraana.
Translated_Text: Three people, three brothers, they drank the ‘toé’.

Primary_Text: Iina mɨɨsaji sɨɨ́sariika, kaa nu=nakarɨɨ́yaa kí=mitɨ́ɨni asúraaja.
Translated_Text: That stingy woman, she doesn’t want to give me manioc.

Primary_Text: Aniwa=aákuji=jaa, kia=kuukisaákari sɨɨ́sariika kia=majáana=jata, kia=mɨra=jata, kaá tɨɨ suwáani iwíini niwa.
Translated_Text: Because of that, if you are stingy with your wife and children, it is not good to live in that way.
All four of us might have drowned.
They suffocated from the smoke.
He denied the accusation that he stole (lit. his theft).
He denied the accusation, (saying) that he had not taken the chicken.

Primary_Text: Iina iijakuuja kí=nikiki aákari taariki=na, iitiika nu=ríkiija siítɨki.
Translated_Text: That anaconda that I saw this morning, its neck reached (i.e., stood off the ground) up to here (with gesture).

Primary_Text: Kamíkuku pɨ=siíyuurɨɨ iina kia=siwanɨɨ́tarɨɨ maámaaja íyɨku.
Translated_Text: On the way upriver we will fish for that (fish) which you will bring to (your) mother’s place.
There he is having sex with his woman/wife.
With his stick, he would poke like this in the sand.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari=na nu=samáraataárikɨ, jawáari=na nu=imɨɨ́tarɨɨ kí=kaakɨ́ɨja=ánuura sikɨ́ɨni, “Ruuu!”
Translated_Text: When he (the jaguar) had rested, afterwards he jumped again towards my father, “Ruuu!”

Primary_Text: Juu, paápaaja anímaakiaakɨ=ná iina asáani=ánuura (iina) nu=sikɨɨkiaakɨ́ tii aasamu=jina.
Translated_Text: Wow, fish came to eat that which he threw there, in the creek.

Primary_Text: Iina maaya nu=sikɨɨ́nii iina piirúuta iina taana maaya.
Translated_Text: The child threw the ball to the other child.

Primary_Text: Púum, nu=sikɨɨkuraaná nu=kusi, pɨyɨ́ɨni pɨyaaja minkáatu.
Translated_Text: Boom, he threw away the pot, the gruel all finished.

Primary_Text: Na=apárakiaakɨ=ná saminiijúuni=jina, iipɨ na=sikɨɨyaárikɨ=na na=mɨra kaámi=na, na=apárakiaakɨ=na iwáani=jina kaamiíraata.
Translated_Text: They began to think, and those who had left their children behind upriver, they began to go upriver.

Primary_Text: Nuú kiaa sikɨɨyaárɨɨ, iyaamiaákuji kaa kia=nakarɨɨ́yaa suwaata iwíini nuu=jata.
Translated_Text: She will leave you, because you don’t want to live well with her.
He leaped up and down (onomatopoeia of movement).
We would wash his clothes.

Primary_Text: Iina nɨsikati takuúyaa naami kí=kurima, kana=sikitaakurá nu=namásikaraata.
Translated_Text: That aguaje palm that is standing there in my port, we were washing behind it.
I am throwing at it with stones.
I am throwing stones at the wooden plank.
Maybe they cast a spell on me.
He has hurt the joint in his right arm.
I saw his barbasco fishing event.
Today I am going to harvest manioc in the afternoon.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari iina aárɨɨyaárikɨ nu=iniimíiku=na, nuu=jata nu=sisiiyaárikɨ nu=nɨɨ́jina.
Translated_Text: When his enemy passed by, with that (i.e., the ‘piripiri’) he pointed at his back.

Primary_Text: Atii=na nu=sisiítakiaaná nuu=karikumaji iina sakújaaja, sáa.
Translated_Text: The he aimed at it from underneath with the ‘piripiri’, saa.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na siwaánɨrɨɨkiaakɨ=na tiímaaka amakɨ=jina, na=tiitakiaakɨ=ná nuu.
Translated_Text: Right then they arrived at a paca path, and they followed it.

Primary_Text: Siwaara júnɨɨna tɨɨ iina irírɨɨ iina maaya.
Translated_Text: It is demon breath that had gotten this child.

Primary_Text: Taapɨ kaaya, miríjaaja=jata nu=sukwáruu waarata kaaya, taana karásiika=jata, taana tipaáka=jata.
Translated_Text: Other people dirtied their fellows with ‘mishquipanga’, others with achiote, others with clay (during Carnival).
The sun though, right there the sun is shining.
This pot, it has a (large) hole in it.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari nu=kuúkirɨɨ irísina jaari=na, wáari nu=inaárikɨ naamɨ=jina nuu, nu=suúkuutáani=íira tii.
Translated_Text: When they got hard, then she would put them on a leaf to cool there.

Primary_Text: Suúkwara k=iíkii iyaamiaákuji kw=ásaki kuuwaa mukuuja.
Translated_Text: I am nauseated because I ate spoiled meat.

Primary_Text: Iina ikwani, kaa kí=niaatíija nakarɨɨyaárikɨ nuu, iyaamiaákuji taárikɨ suúkwara kuwasiáana n=ani.
Translated_Text: That man, my mother didn’t like him, because his mother was an argumentative person.

Primary_Text: Náaji=na suúkwara miiyáana=na kiáaja=na, kia=asatɨɨ́kiaana kia=íiki ímani=na kanáaja iina paápaaja.
Translated_Text: Then you are a disgusting person, you make us eat fish that you catch with your poop.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari taa=na suwáani iina sinaakɨ=na, kaa nu=kuutiíkiaana.
Translated_Text: When clothing is good, it doesn’t tear.
You are beautiful today, Aunt.

Primary_Text: Iina maaya taá ariwatɨɨyáana=na, suwáani tɨɨ, suwáani maaya.
Translated_Text: The child that is obedient is good, a good child.

Primary_Text: Atii=na iina mɨɨsaji nu=sakɨɨkuraaná suwaata nu=itíniija.
Translated_Text: Then the woman chewed her manioc beer (mash) well.
I cut with my right hand.

Primary_Text: Kinikíira kia=iíkwaki kiina iíkuma amakɨ iina iíkwaa pɨ́=suwákiji.
Translated_Text: Go over there on the path that goes to the right.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari kí=miiyaárikɨ súwaramaajɨtáami kásiiri manaja kíija=na, wáari kana=iíkwakiaakɨ Pucallpa=jina, na=akumitɨ́ɨni=íira kanáaja.
Translated_Text: When I had been pregrant for four months, then we went to Pucallpa, so that they would get us married.

Primary_Text: Nu=jikukiaakɨ kanaájawaaka: kíija, taana kí=kujímani ɨɨ́yaaka taárikɨ Eliodoro.
Translated_Text: He sent us: me and another companion of mine whose name was Eliodoro.

Primary_Text: Iipɨ=na taapɨ kitaákayuuri, nu=aátikiaakɨ náaji, “Saakaa=aákuji=na iina miiyaákiaana kitáaka pɨyɨ́ɨni saakaaya=na?”
Translated_Text: Those other young women, they said, “Why does that young woman have everything?”
I will look for another.
That is his food.

Primary_Text: Na=nakusiaárikɨ=na, “Pɨ́=kumáani p=ɨ́tuukiaaná pɨyɨ́ɨni iipɨ taá kanɨɨrɨ miiyáapɨ.”
Translated_Text: They knew, “God is going to burn all of us who are sinners.”

Primary_Text: Kuupɨ taárikɨ kanáaja, kuupɨ mɨɨsaji taárikɨ kanáaja.
Translated_Text: We were two, we were two women.
He is shamanically associated with an animal.

Primary_Text: Kaa nuu, iina mɨɨsaji, kaa nu=nakusiaárikɨ kánɨɨka táaja.
Translated_Text: She didn’t, the woman, she didn’t know who it was.

Primary_Text: Kiaá nuu paaniki, taákari, nu=iíkii atií=yaa tii iita=siriku.
Translated_Text: You look for it, and at another time, it is right there at the side of the house.
On another day, he would kill a White-lipped Peccary.
He already went somewhere else.

Primary_Text: Atií=yaa imɨráani, taaki=ji, kuumi káaniu, traa!
Translated_Text: Right then, again, from the other side, the second barrel (of the shotgun), traa!

Primary_Text: Iyaákari=íira=ná=yaa=jaa nu=kuúkikiaakɨ júura kumaati, nu=apárakiaakɨ=ná taaki saminiijúuni=jina.
Translated_Text: Until that moment when she became very old and began to think in another way (i.e., became evil).
If she lost her way along a different path, we will not be able to find her.
And then he cured him, just like that, from a distance.

Primary_Text: Taapɨ, iipɨ=na nakusiijiaárikɨ=na kaa ariwáani=na, taama=na na=iíkii=kíyaa paapa.
Translated_Text: Others, those who didn’t know how to sing, they just stay quiet.

Primary_Text: Kí=nakúsii taamá=yaa nuu, náaji jɨɨ́ta nuúkiika makɨ́ɨni=jina.
Translated_Text: I know him the littlest bit, like in a dream.

Primary_Text: Kaa taama aniáana kíija nami=ji k=iyáma=ji; iyaamiaákuji ki=níyaaka iwɨɨ́rɨkiáakɨ; niwa=aákuji kw=aníkiaakɨ iiti.
Translated_Text: I didn’t come (here) from my homestead there downriver for no good reason; because my husband died; that’s why I came here.

Primary_Text: Nu=iíkuuyaárɨɨkiaakɨ=na tíira niíkuma, taamá=yaa tíira naki=jinakuma.
Translated_Text: He went walking along the path, aimlessly through the forest.
Falsely he said, “I will live again.”
No, you’re joking (he said).

Primary_Text: Taama miíniika=na nu=siwaánɨrɨɨkiaakɨ=ná=yaa tíira iitakúura, ninɨ́ɨni=aákuji.
Translated_Text: He just barely arrived at the house (since he was badly injured), in the afternoon.
She may become sick any day.

Primary_Text: Nu=ajaárikɨ naajaá nu=íyiki, taamaárika nu=íyiki=na, aráaku.
Translated_Text: She ground (corn) at her place also, her own place, (her) burrow.
With her own ‘piripiri’ he killed her.
By myself with my own thinking I learned that.
“Aa,” he said to himself, “Aa.”

Primary_Text: Kia=akɨ tarawaájuuyaa taamaárika, kí=tarawaájuuyaa kí=nasi taamaárika.
Translated_Text: Your father works separately, and I work my garden separately.

Primary_Text: Atii k=inataániikurá na=itíniija naawaaka, na=raríini=íira taamaárika.
Translated_Text: Then I put down manioc beer for them, for them (the men) to drink separately.

Primary_Text: Náaji kumɨɨja tɨɨ kíija, taara míini=jata.
Translated_Text: Thus I grew up, in poverty.

Primary_Text: Kaá tɨɨ náaji jɨɨ́ta taárikɨ taarí=yaajaa.
Translated_Text: It isn’t like it was before.
Before, it is said, our ancestors, they were shamans.
Every morning she went to harvest manioc.
In the morning, I put my pots there (upriver) already.
The ‘ayahuasca’ has gone bad in his body.

Primary_Text: Iina aákuta, nu=taásikura, iyaamiaákuji iina siimana kaa nu=kariíniikurá nuu.
Translated_Text: This ‘ayahuasca’ has gone bad, because the shaman did not watch over it.
He has ruined his diet in his body.

Primary_Text: Jaari=na, nu=siwaánɨrɨɨkiaakɨ=ná tii nu=majáana iyikíira, taana nu=majáana iyikíira, taasíita nu=majáana.
Translated_Text: So then he arrived there at his wife’s residence, his other wife’s place, his real wife.

Primary_Text: Kaá tɨɨ=kija iyaamiaákuji taárikɨ taasíita nɨ́yini.
Translated_Text: But it was not because he was his true son.
Then she really killed it.

Primary_Text: Jaa kana=takátarɨɨ kana=iímina, jaa nuúruu aátataárɨɨ.
Translated_Text: We had tipped the canoe, and the ‘barbasco’ had gone downriver.

Primary_Text: Íyaa iina=na, taákari yaawɨ́ɨni iina siwaánɨrɨɨkiaaná waarata mɨɨsaji, nuúkiika mɨɨsajiika náaji pɨ́=nikii takínuurikɨɨka náaji, mɨɨsajiika.
Translated_Text: So then, one day, another woman like her arrived, a woman that we’d see as short, a little woman.
There he rolled back and forth from the pain (when) his eyes burst.
There, they say, she danced in circles with them.
That standing right there is a tiger heron!
Right away (sound of sudden movement), the man stood up.
His height is just up to there (with gesture).
He is building his house walls.
He is building a corral for his pigs.

Primary_Text: Iina míisi, nu=tasínakiki kíija pɨyɨ́ɨni nu=awákukwa=jata.
Translated_Text: That cat scratched me badly with all of its claws.
She is propping here paddle there (against the wall).
All of his dogs are ‘daredevils’ (bold and fearless).

Primary_Text: Kií=ta kápuuyaa tii pɨ́=tasikɨ, tɨɨ nu=pajátɨrɨɨ.
Translated_Text: I was repairing our fish trap there, where it had gotten a hole.
All of them had passed to the other side of the creek.
I was sitting over there.

Primary_Text: Kapiki iina asúraaja tiírajiina, iina taana nasikuúra=jina.
Translated_Text: Cook this manioc (that originates) from over there, from that other chacra.

Primary_Text: Átiiji=na=jaa, na=makɨkiáakɨ nuu=siriku, iina taana tíirajiita, naajaa iítijiita iina taana.
Translated_Text: So then, they slept by his side, the one on the other side and the other on this side.
Walk along there (indicating a path in the distance).

Primary_Text: Nu=siwaánɨrɨɨkiaakɨ=ná tɨɨti=na iipɨ iikiaárikɨ=na siíruwa, maasiáana síruku=na.
Translated_Text: He arrived where the woolly monkeys lived, lots of woolly monkeys.

Primary_Text: Iina nu=sapukwaka, anuu kia=kɨyɨɨ́taki tɨɨti iina ítuu kiáaja muúkwaaya.
Translated_Text: That froth, you rub that on wherever the rainbow burned you.

Primary_Text: Jawáari na=aátikiaakɨ kanáaja, “Aájapaki tɨɨ tɨɨti kinaa tikiaárɨɨ.”
Translated_Text: Then later they told us, “There is nowhere for you to enter.”
Wife, where have you gone?

Primary_Text: Na=tiitakiaakɨ=ná iina aaka, kaa na=nakusiaárikɨ=na tɨɨ́tiiji iina ánii aaka.
Translated_Text: They followed the river, and they didn’t know where the river came from.

Primary_Text: K=iikwaákiaana náaji yaawɨ́ɨni=ánuura, náaji yaawɨ́ɨni, tijiíraki pɨ́=titika=iíkwaji.
Translated_Text: I’m going for 15 days, this many (10 fingers) and one side of a foot.
I am going to enter your house.
Up to here (with only one hand above water) I had sunk in the water.
The painted designs look the same.
That (weedy grass) is equal (in height) to the manioc (plants).
With her, we would go around together, (I) with her.
A cursed night eater lives down in Saboya.

Primary_Text: Iina kɨriija, nu=tipɨki iina=jina náana ákika.
Translated_Text: The pitch stuck to the tree branches.
The bird got stuck in the pitch.
You will travel to various places looking for manioc.
They are sitting in various places.
The strong sun quickly dried my clothes.

Primary_Text: “Aákari tuu, kia=ánaajɨki,” nɨɨtamu aátikiaakɨ=ná iina mɨɨsaji.
Translated_Text: “Now you have really healed,” the vulture said to the woman.

Primary_Text: Jawaári=na=wa tuu, iina mɨɨsaji iíkwakura tíira.
Translated_Text: After that indeed, the woman went over there.
Go gather a lot of achiote.

Primary_Text: Nu=tikiaárɨɨkiaaná takinakúura, maakwaárika, kaa uumáata áriitáani=jata, náaji maakwaárika, kaa samuu tuujíini=íira nuu.
Translated_Text: He entered the lake slowly, without paddling much, slowly, so that the ‘paiche’ would not hear him.
You were upriver for a long time!
“I am very tired,” he responded to my late mother.

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́tikari nu=ipaásii=na, wáari kiaá nuu raatiki.
Translated_Text: When it has fermented, then you will drink it.
If you get healthy, then you will work.
Gut the fish in the meantime, nephew, for us to cook.
In the meantime, I’ll get the fire going.
They are making fariña (various batches in various places).

Primary_Text: Kí=nakarɨɨ́yaa nuúkiika kusi kɨráani waáriká=yaajaa, nuúkiika kusi amɨ́yaja asúraaja kɨráani.
Translated_Text: I just want to peel one potful, to peel one full potful of manioc.
Just go right away.
Now (unlike before) he finds lots of pacas.
As for the macaw, he arrived at the other side.
Wife, where are you?

Primary_Text: Jɨɨ́ta=na nu=sikɨɨkuraaná iina sɨɨ́saramaajɨtáami paatíina aaka=jina, na=tuújiikuraaná iina aaka, na=tuújiikuraaná aaka wɨɨrɨ́ɨni, Siuuu!
Translated_Text: As he threw the three pieces of balsa wood into the water, they heard the water roar, Shuuu!

Primary_Text: Kutatáani=aákuji, jɨɨ́tikari kaakáraaja wɨɨrɨɨ́yaa, wáari kií=ta makɨɨ́taa nuu (kw=aníriti).
Translated_Text: In the wee hours (this morning), when the rooster crows, then I was dreaming of her (my aunt).
All of our things were coming in the riverboat.
They began to count (lit. measure) the days.
The day had dawned
Now is horsefly season.

Primary_Text: Niwa=aákuji iipɨ maakatúuwa na=aatiaárikɨ náaji, “Kuumi yaawɨ́ɨni na=aámuukiaakɨ=ná iina nawɨyini.”
Translated_Text: For this reason the ancestors said, “That ghost died two times.”
